questions.text:
The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set.
For each patient with altered mental status, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 57-year-old man is brought to the physician for worsening mental status over the past 2 months. His wife reports that he was initially experiencing lapses in memory, and over the past 3 weeks, he has started having difficulty performing activities of daily living. Yesterday, he got lost going to the post office down the street. He has hypertension treated with lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is alert but verbally uncommunicative. Muscle strength is normal. Reflexes are 2+ in bilateral upper and lower extremities. He has diffuse involuntary muscle jerking that can be provoked by loud noises. Mental status examination shows a blunt affect. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of glucose, creatinine, and electrolytes are within the reference range.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although Alzheimer disease initially manifests with short-term memory loss and temporospatial disorientation, as seen in this patient, impaired naming and language comprehension, as well as mood and behavioral changes would also be prominent. Myoclonus does not occur in the early stages of Alzheimer disease. Most importantly, Alzheimer disease has an insidious onset and progresses slowly over several years, whereas this patient's symptoms progressed rapidly within 2 months.

B) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease may manifest with signs of dementia, but the hallmark findings of Parkinson disease are bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremor, which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Huntington disease (HD) manifests with movement abnormalities and the defining symptom is chorea, which is absent in this patient. Furthermore, myoclonus is an atypical symptom of HD that occurs only rarely. Neuropsychiatric symptoms such as dementia and apathy can occur but appear at advanced stages, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Rapidly progressing mental decline combined with myoclonus and mutism, as seen in this patient, are typical clinical findings in patients with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. The disease has a rapid course that often leads to death within 12 months.

E) INCORRECT:

Although amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) typically manifests in patients between 50 and 60 years and may cause cognitive impairment in some patients, memory loss is not a typical early finding in this disease. Additionally, ALS manifests with asymmetric limb weakness, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness, which are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

F) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) may manifest in some patients with memory deficits but this usually occurs as a very late feature. Additionally, MS typically manifests with impaired vision, color blindness, Lhermitte sign, absence of abdominal reflex, and signs of upper motor neuron dysfunction (e.g., spasticity, positive Babinski sign), none of which are present in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients with Wilson disease may present with cognitive impairment and myoclonus, but neurologic features, such as dysarthria, parkinsonism, and drooling, are much more common. Other typical findings of Wilson disease, such as liver damage and Kayser-Fleischer rings, are also absent. Finally, the disease typically manifests in patients < 35 years of age.

H) INCORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus may manifest with signs of dementia, but clinical features also include gait disturbances and urinary incontinence, which this patient lacks. Additionally, normal pressure hydrocephalus usually presents in older patients (> 60 years of age) or as a consequence of CNS infections and intracranial hemorrhages.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

I) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia is characterized by early changes in personality and behavior (e.g., inappropriate social behavior) while memory and orientation initially remain intact, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.
questions.hint: The electroencephalogram of this patient with rapidly progressing symptoms of dementia would show triphasic periodic sharp-wave complexes.

questions.text:
For each patient with altered mental status, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 55-year-old man is brought to the physician because of inappropriate behavior for the past 6 months. He has been making inappropriate comments and jokes while talking to friends and family members. He was arrested 3 weeks ago while trying to kiss strangers on the street. He also has lost interest in talking to his daughter or playing with his grandchildren. During this period, he has developed a strong desire for chocolate pudding and potato chips and has gained 10 kg (22 lb). He appears unkempt. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Mental status examination shows apathy and a blunt affect. He avoids answering questions and instead comments on the individuals he saw in the waiting room. Mini-Mental State Examination score is 28/30. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of glucose, creatinine, and electrolytes are within the reference range.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease (AD) manifests with cognitive and behavioral changes. However, AD usually is associated with short-term memory loss and temporospatial disorientation, which are absent in this patient. Additionally, AD usually has an insidious progression, whereas this patient's symptoms have progressed over the course of 6 months.

B) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease (PD) may cause personality changes, especially in advanced disease. However, patients with PD also present with bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremor, which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Advanced cases of Huntington disease manifest with apathy and other behavioral changes, as seen in this patient. However, this condition has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and typically also manifests with abnormal (choreiform) movements, which are absent in this patient. Huntington disease may manifest without a family history, but this is a very rare event, occurring only in 1–3% of cases.

D) INCORRECT:

Although Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease may manifest with signs and symptoms of dementia such as the behavioral and personality changes seen in this patient, however, the neurologic deterioration in this disease usually occurs more rapidly, taking place over the course of weeks-to-months and resulting in death within ∼ 1 year of symptom onset. Patients would also present with other neurological manifestations such as myoclonic jerks, gait instability, seizures, and/or hallucinations.

E) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) typically manifests in patients 50–60 years old and may cause behavioral changes in late stages of the disease. However, ALS causes chronic, progressive, asymmetric limb weakness, fasciculations, cramps, and muscle stiffness, which are absent in this patient.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

F) INCORRECT:

Advanced multiple sclerosis (MS) may cause cognitive changes in some patients. However, patients with MS have a history of relapsing/remitting weakness, numbness, and loss of balance, none of which are present in this patient. Additionally, MS typically manifests with impaired vision, color blindness, Lhermitte sign, absent abdominal reflex, and/or signs of upper motor neuron dysfunction (e.g., spasticity, positive Babinski sign), which are also absent in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Although Wilson disease may cause behavioral changes, this condition usually manifests with liver disease and neurologic features such as dysarthria, parkinsonism, and drooling, which this patient does not have. Additionally, the disease typically manifests in patients < 35 years of age.

H) INCORRECT:

Although normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is a potential cause of dementia, this condition typically manifests with gait disturbances, cognitive dysfunction, and urinary incontinence (“wet, wacky, and wobbly”), which this patient lacks. Additionally, NPH usually manifests in older patients (> 60 years of age) or as a consequence of CNS infections and intracranial hemorrhages.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

I) CORRECT:

Personality changes, disinhibited behavior, and binge-eating (particularly sweet foods) in a middle-aged adult with intact memory are highly suspicious for frontotemporal dementia. This condition has a rapid progression compared to other dementias (see “Differential diagnosis of subtypes of dementia” table), with patients surviving an average of approximately 6–9 years after symptom onset. In later stages, parkinsonism is also common. Diagnosis is made clinically, and can be supported via neuroimaging (MRI showing atrophy of the frontal and/or temporal lobes) and FDG-PET/CT (showing frontotemporal hypoperfusion and hypometabolism).
questions.hint: This patient presents with a condition that is generally associated with pathological intracellular inclusion bodies, which are usually caused by mutations in tau proteins.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of strange behavior and emotional outbursts for the past 6 months. He was previously healthy and physically active, but he recently started binge-eating candy and stopped exercising. He was fired from his job for inappropriate behavior after he undressed in the office and made lewd remarks to several female coworkers. He claims there is nothing wrong with his behavior. On mental status examination, he is alert and irritable but cooperative. Short-term recall is normal but he has some word-finding difficulties. This patient's symptoms are most likely due to a degenerative process in which of the following regions of the brain?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A degenerative process of the frontal cortex is seen in frontotemporal dementia (FTD). The frontal lobes are involved in many aspects of cognition and behavior, including personality, emotion, judgment, voluntary movement, problem-solving, and attention. FTD can manifest with changes in personality, disruptive social behavior, and aphasia, as seen in this patient. Symptoms appearing later in the course of the disease include parkinsonism, disorientation, and memory impairment.

B) INCORRECT:

A degenerative process of the substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson disease, multiple system atrophy, and Lewy body dementia. These conditions can manifest with dementia and personality changes, which are seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks the prominent parkinsonism (e.g., bradykinesia, tremor) that is typically present with involvement of the substantia nigra.

C) INCORRECT:

A degenerative process of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington disease. This hereditary condition can manifest with dementia, personality changes, and hyperreflexia, which are seen in this patient. However, he lacks the involuntary motor symptoms (e.g., chorea) typically seen with degeneration of the caudate nucleus.

D) INCORRECT:

A degenerative process of the hippocampus can be seen in conditions such as Alzheimer disease (AD), mesial temporal sclerosis, or temporal lobe epilepsy. The emotional instability and aphasia in this patient could be consistent with Alzheimer disease but he lacks the memory deficits that would be expected with degeneration of the hippocampus.

E) INCORRECT:

Distortion of the fibers of the corona radiata is seen in normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), which classically presents with dementia, urinary incontinence, and ataxia. The absence of urinary incontinence and ataxia makes degeneration of the corona radiata an unlikely etiology of his symptoms.
questions.hint: The development of disinhibited behavior (e.g., hypersexuality), exaggerated emotional display, binge-eating, aphasia, and primitive reflexes in a male between the ages of 40–60 years suggests dementia with degeneration in the region of the brain responsible, in part, for personality, judgment, and emotion.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for a psychiatric evaluation. Over the past 12 months, his behavior has become increasingly disruptive. His wife no longer brings him along shopping because he has attempted to grope a female cashier on 2 occasions. He has begun to address the mail carrier using a racial epithet. Three years later, the patient dies. Light microscopy of sections of the frontal and temporal lobes shows intracellular inclusions of transactive response DNA binding protein (TDP-43). These proteins are bound to a regulatory molecule that usually marks them for degradation. The regulatory molecule in question is most likely which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tau proteins stabilize microtubules. Abnormal aggregates of tau proteins are seen in various neurodegenerative brain diseases, including Alzheimer disease and frontotemporal dementia, the diagnosis in this patient. However, tau proteins do not mark protein targets for degradation.

B) INCORRECT:

Kinesin and dynein are motor proteins involved in transport along microtubules (e.g., movement of synaptic vesicles along axons). Mutations in genes encoding kinesin family proteins have been found in hereditary nerve disorders such as Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. However, kinesin does not mark other proteins for degradation.

C) INCORRECT:

Cyclins control the cell cycle and transitions between cell cycle phases. Cyclin dysfunction can lead to uncontrolled cell division that causes malignancy. Cyclins do not mark protein targets for degradation.

D) CORRECT:

Tagging with ubiquitin marks proteins for degradation by the ubiquitin-proteasome system (UPS). Dysfunction of the UPS is implicated in various neurodegenerative brain diseases, including frontotemporal dementia, as seen here, as well as Alzheimer disease, Parkinson disease, and Huntington disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Chaperone proteins assist in molecular assembly and folding of other proteins. Defects or losses of chaperone proteins can lead to protein misfolding and contribute to neurodegeneration as seen in this patient. However, chaperone proteins do not mark other proteins for degradation.

F) INCORRECT:

Clathrin is a protein that coats vesicles and assists in vesicular endocytosis and trafficking. Although dysfunction of clathrin-mediated endocytosis is hypothesized to be involved in the development of some neurodegenerative brain diseases, clathrin does not mark protein targets for degradation.
questions.hint: This man had frontotemporal dementia, which causes changes in personality and social behavior. The postmortem histopathologic findings of intracellular inclusions of TDP-43 in the frontal and temporal lobes confirms the diagnosis. Binding of the regulatory molecule in question to proteins such as TDP-43 normally results in transport of the proteins to the proteasome.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, and recently diagnosed type 2 diabetes presents for evaluation of functional decline. Her husband reports that during the past 3 years, she has had difficulty caring for herself and has undergone significant personality changes. For example, she has begun hoarding newspapers and magazines and has dedicated an entire room to organizing and maintaining her collection. She has also begun to show very little concern for her husband’s health, even though he is undergoing treatment for prostate cancer. In addition, she has developed a predilection for sweet foods and has gained 30 kg in body weight.
On physical examination, she appears older than her stated age, and her affect is flattened. She is afebrile and has a heart rate of 76 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 142/78 mm Hg. Her lungs are clear to auscultation, and her cardiac examination is normal with a prominent fourth heart sound. She has mild, symmetric peripheral edema. On neurologic examination, she is attentive and oriented. She has significant difficulty with the Trail Making Test and with verbal fluency, but recent recall and remote episodic memory are relatively intact. She completes the clock-drawing task correctly but slowly. Grasp and snout reflexes are present. She has no tremor, and her gait is normal.
A complete blood count is normal. Additional laboratory testing is notable only for a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 6.5 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.7) and a vitamin B12 level of 780 pg/mL (>250). Treponemal antibody testing is negative.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease is more prominently associated with memory difficulties than frontotemporal dementia is. Executive dysfunction often occurs as the disease progresses, years after onset. Apathy, lack of empathy, and compulsive behaviors are not prominent early in the disease but can occur later.

B) CORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia is the fourth most common type of dementia, behind Alzheimer disease, vascular dementia, and dementia with Lewy bodies. It tends to manifest at a younger age than Alzheimer disease (typically in the sixth decade) and can progress at a faster rate. The most common type of frontotemporal dementia is behavioral variant, which manifests with personality changes and abnormal behaviors — and is often misdiagnosed as psychiatric illness. Common changes include verbal and sexual disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy, compulsive behaviors, and altered dietary preferences (including a predilection for sweets). Frontotemporal dementia can also manifest with aphasia, but this is less common.

Neuropsychological testing in patients with frontotemporal dementia typically reveals difficulty with verbal fluency and executive functioning, such as on the Trail Making Test. Neuroimaging typically reveals atrophy of the frontal lobe, temporal lobe, or both, and the atrophy can be asymmetric across the hemispheres. Management is supportive, with symptomatic treatment for psychosis or depression if necessary.

Key learning point: Personality changes (including onset of obsessive or hoarding behaviors and lack of empathy), difficulties with executive function, and frontal release signs on examination are most suggestive of frontotemporal dementia.

C) INCORRECT:

Dementia with Lewy bodies is diagnosed based on the presence of at least two of the following features: spontaneous parkinsonism (usually occurring at some point after or in synchrony with dementia), visual hallucinations, rapid-eye-movement sleep behavior disorder, and waxing and waning alertness and attention. Other supportive features include autonomic dysfunction, recurrent falls, sensitivity to neuroleptic agents, delusions, hyposmia, and psychiatric illness. This patient has a blunt affect, which could be confused with masked facies, and her personality changes could be confused with other psychiatric illnesses. However, the overall pattern of findings in this patient is more consistent with frontotemporal dementia than with Lewy body dementia.

D) INCORRECT:

Although hypothyroidism can cause depressive-type symptoms, it is unlikely to explain this patient’s overall presentation (e.g., the hoarding and frontal release signs), and her thyroid-stimulating hormone level is only slightly elevated.

E) INCORRECT:

Depression can be misdiagnosed as dementia. Patients with mood disorders may develop changes in appetite (although not necessarily a preference for sweets) and may withdraw socially. They may also have cognitive problems (particularly related to attention), and examination may reveal difficulties with multistep tasks that require attention. However, in the absence of dementia, patients with depression do not have frontal release signs (such as grasp and snout reflexes) or difficulty with executive function tasks, such as the Trail Making Test.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man is brought to the office by his wife because of strange behavior and emotional outbursts for the past 6 months. He was previously healthy and physically active, but he recently started binge-eating candy and stopped exercising. He was fired from his job for inappropriate behavior after he undressed in the office and made lewd remarks to several female coworkers. Short-term recall is normal but he has some word-finding difficulties. This patient's symptoms are most likely due to a degenerative process in which of the following regions of the brain?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A degenerative process of the frontal cortex is seen in frontotemporal dementia (FTD). The frontal lobes are involved in many aspects of cognition and behavior, including personality, emotion, judgment, voluntary movement, problem-solving, and attention. FTD can manifest with changes in personality, disruptive social behavior, and aphasia, as seen in this patient. Symptoms appearing later in the course of the disease include parkinsonism, disorientation, and memory impairment.

B) INCORRECT:

A degenerative process of the substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson disease, multiple system atrophy, and Lewy body dementia. These conditions can manifest with dementia and personality changes, which are seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks the prominent parkinsonism (e.g., bradykinesia, tremor) that is typically present with involvement of the substantia nigra.

C) INCORRECT:

A degenerative process of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington disease. This hereditary condition can manifest with dementia, personality changes, and hyperreflexia, which are seen in this patient. However, he lacks the involuntary motor symptoms (e.g., chorea) typically seen with degeneration of the caudate nucleus.

D) INCORRECT:

A degenerative process of the hippocampus can be seen in conditions such as Alzheimer disease (AD), mesial temporal sclerosis, or temporal lobe epilepsy. The emotional instability and aphasia in this patient could be consistent with Alzheimer disease but he lacks the memory deficits that would be expected with degeneration of the hippocampus.

E) INCORRECT:

Distortion of the fibers of the corona radiata is seen in normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), which classically presents with dementia, urinary incontinence, and ataxia. The absence of urinary incontinence and ataxia makes degeneration of the corona radiata an unlikely etiology of his symptoms.
questions.hint: The development of disinhibited behavior (e.g., hypersexuality), exaggerated emotional display, binge-eating, aphasia, and primitive reflexes in a male between the ages of 40–60 years suggests dementia with degeneration in the region of the brain responsible, in part, for personality, judgment, and emotion.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his partner for progressive personality changes over 8 months. He has become disinhibited, disregarding social norms, and has developed new compulsive behaviors, but has no significant memory deficits. His speech is halting with word-finding difficulties. Neurologic examination is normal (see report).
MRI of the brain: Focal atrophy in the frontal and anterior temporal regions
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vascular dementia often presents with stepwise cognitive decline and focal neurological deficits due to cerebrovascular events. Imaging typically shows multiple infarcts or white matter changes, not focal atrophy. The patient's gradual personality changes and MRI findings suggest a neurodegenerative process rather than a vascular etiology.

B) CORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) manifests in patients in their 50s to 60s with significant personality changes, social disinhibition, and language difficulties. This condition involves degeneration of the frontal and anterior temporal lobes, which regulate social norms and language. The patient's disinhibition, compulsive behaviors, and speech difficulties align with FTD. MRI findings of focal atrophy in these regions further support the diagnosis. Memory is often preserved in early FTD, distinguishing it from other dementias where memory impairment is an early feature.

Key learning point: Frontotemporal dementia often presents with personality changes, irritability, and language difficulties, distinguishing it from other types of dementia such as Alzheimer's disease, which typically begins with memory impairment.

C) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer's disease typically presents with early episodic memory deficits and impaired new memory formation, which are not prominent in this patient. Neuroimaging in Alzheimer's often shows diffuse or medial temporal lobe atrophy, particularly affecting the hippocampi, unlike the focal frontal and anterior temporal atrophy seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Dementia with Lewy bodies is characterized by fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonian symptoms, which are absent in this patient. Neuroimaging usually does not show pronounced focal atrophy in the frontal and anterior temporal regions, unlike the findings in this case.

questions.text: You are seeing a 53-year-old man who is brought to your clinic by his wife because of 6 months of unusual behavior and emotional outbursts. He was previously healthy and physically active, but recently began binge-eating candy and stopped exercising. He lost his job after undressing at work and making inappropriate remarks to female coworkers. On assessment, his short-term recall is normal, but he has some word-finding difficulties. Which one of the following regions of the brain is most likely affected by a degenerative process causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A degenerative process of the frontal cortex is seen in frontotemporal dementia (FTD). The frontal lobes are involved in many aspects of cognition and behavior, including personality, emotion, judgment, voluntary movement, problem-solving, and attention. FTD can manifest with changes in personality, disruptive social behavior, and aphasia, as seen in this patient. Symptoms appearing later in the course of the disease include parkinsonism, disorientation, and memory impairment.

Key learning point: Frontotemporal dementia is characterized by degeneration of the frontal cortex, leading to personality changes, disinhibition, and language difficulties.

B) INCORRECT:

Distortion of the fibers of the corona radiata is seen in normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), which classically presents with dementia, urinary incontinence, and ataxia. The absence of urinary incontinence and ataxia makes degeneration of the corona radiata an unlikely etiology of his symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

A degenerative process of the substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson disease, multiple system atrophy, and Lewy body dementia. These conditions can manifest with dementia and personality changes, which are seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks the prominent parkinsonism (e.g., bradykinesia, tremor) that is typically present with involvement of the substantia nigra.

D) INCORRECT:

A degenerative process of the hippocampus can be seen in conditions such as Alzheimer disease (AD), mesial temporal sclerosis, or temporal lobe epilepsy. The emotional instability and aphasia in this patient could be consistent with Alzheimer disease but he lacks the memory deficits that would be expected with degeneration of the hippocampus.

E) INCORRECT:

A degenerative process of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington disease. This hereditary condition can manifest with dementia, personality changes, and hyperreflexia, which are seen in this patient. However, he lacks the involuntary motor symptoms (e.g., chorea) typically seen with degeneration of the caudate nucleus.
questions.hint: The development of disinhibited behavior (e.g., hypersexuality), exaggerated emotional display, binge-eating, aphasia, and primitive reflexes in a male between the ages of 40–60 years suggests dementia with degeneration in the region of the brain responsible, in part, for personality, judgment, and emotion.
